stem: A client is using peritoneal dialysis (PD) at home. Based on the documentation, which finding is the most definitive indicator that the client has developed peritonitis?

rationale.correct: While a cloudy appearance (a1) is an early visual cue, an effluent WBC count of 1,200/mm³ (a2) is the most definitive clinical indicator of peritonitis in a PD patient. A WBC count >100/mm³ with >50% neutrophils in the dialysate is diagnostic. The cloudy appearance is caused by the accumulation of white blood cells and bacteria.
clinicalPearls: Normal PD effluent is clear and straw-colored, allowing visibility through the bag.
Cloudy effluent indicates peritonitis, a common PD complication.
Blood-tinged effluent can be normal in menstruating women or after catheter placement; cloudy effluent is never normal.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting 'Cloudy appearance' (a1) because it's a common sign.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize objective laboratory confirmation over subjective/visual findings. WBC count is the gold standard for peritonitis diagnosis.

mnemonic.title: PD Effluent
mnemonic.expansion: Clear is good, cloudy is bad. High WBCs make the nurse sad.
